The Committee from time to time shall revise its price determinations with respect to those products and services in accordance with changing market conditions.

subsection.heading: Central Nonprofit Agency or Agencies .—
subsection.content: The Committee shall designate a central nonprofit agency or agencies to facilitate the distribution, by direct allocation, subcontract, or any other means, of orders of the Federal Government for products and services on the procurement list among qualified nonprofit agencies for the blind or qualified nonprofit agencies for other severely disabled.

subsection.heading: Regulations .—
subsection.chapeau: The Committee—

paragraph.content: may prescribe regulations regarding specifications for products and services on the procurement list, the time of their delivery, and other matters as necessary to carry out this chapter; and

shall prescribe regulations providing that when the Federal Government purchases products produced and offered for sale by qualified nonprofit agencies for the blind or qualified nonprofit agencies for other severely disabled, priority shall be given to products produced and offered for sale by qualified nonprofit agencies for the blind.

subsection.heading: Study and Evaluation of Activities .—
subsection.chapeau: The Committee shall make a continuing study and evaluation of its activities under this chapter to ensure effective and efficient administration of this chapter. The Committee on its own or in cooperation with other public or nonprofit private agencies may study—

paragraph.content: problems related to the employment of the blind and other severely disabled individuals; and
the development and adaptation of production methods that would enable a greater utilization of the blind and other severely disabled individuals.

section.heading: Procurement requirements for the Federal Government

subsection.heading: In General .—
subsection.content: An entity of the Federal Government intending to procure a product or service on the procurement list referred to in section 8503 of this title shall procure the product or service from a qualified nonprofit agency for the blind or a qualified nonprofit agency for other severely disabled in accordance with regulations of the Committee and at the price the Committee establishes if the product or service is available within the period required by the entity.

subsection.heading: Exception .—
subsection.content: This section does not apply to the procurement of a product that is available from an industry established under chapter 307 of title 18 and that is required under section 4124 of title 18 to be procured from that industry.

section.heading: Audit
section.chapeau: For the purpose of audit and examination, the Comptroller General shall have access to the books, documents, papers, and other records of—

paragraph.content: the Committee and of each central nonprofit agency the Committee designates under section 8503(c) of this title ; and

qualified nonprofit agencies for the blind and qualified nonprofit agencies for other severely disabled that have sold products or services under this chapter to the extent those books, documents, papers, and other records relate to the activities of the agency in a fiscal year in which a sale was made under this chapter.

content.p: Necessary amounts may be appropriated to the Committee to carry out this chapter.

section.heading: Definitions
section.chapeau: In this chapter:

paragraph.heading: Contracting agency .—
paragraph.content: The term “contracting agency”, when used with respect to a prime contractor, means a department, agency, or establishment of the Federal Government that enters into a prime contract with a prime contractor.

paragraph.heading: Kickback .—
paragraph.content: The term “kickback” means any money, fee, commission, credit, gift, gratuity, thing of value, or compensation of any kind that is provided to a prime contractor, prime contractor employee, subcontractor, or subcontractor employee to improperly obtain or reward favorable treatment in connection with a prime contract or a subcontract relating to a prime contract.

paragraph.heading: Person .—
paragraph.content: The term “person” means a corporation, partnership, business association of any kind, trust, joint-stock company, or individual.

paragraph.heading: Prime contract .—
paragraph.content: The term “prime contract” means a contract or contractual action entered into by the Federal Government to obtain supplies, materials, equipment, or services of any kind.

paragraph.heading: Prime contractor .—
paragraph.content: The term “prime contractor” means a person that has entered into a prime contract with the Federal Government.

paragraph.heading: Prime contractor employee .—
paragraph.content: The term “prime contractor employee” means an officer, partner, employee, or agent of a prime contractor.

paragraph.heading: Subcontract .—
paragraph.content: The term “subcontract” means a contract or contractual action entered into by a prime contractor or subcontractor to obtain supplies, materials, equipment, or services of any kind under a prime contract.

paragraph.heading: Subcontractor .—
paragraph.chapeau: The term “subcontractor”—

subparagraph.content: means a person, other than the prime contractor, that offers to furnish or furnishes supplies, materials, equipment, or services of any kind under a prime contract or a subcontract entered into in connection with the prime contract; and
includes a person that offers to furnish or furnishes general supplies to the prime contractor or a higher tier subcontractor.

paragraph.heading: Subcontractor employee .—
paragraph.content: The term “subcontractor employee” means an officer, partner, employee, or agent of a subcontractor.

section.heading: Prohibited conduct
section.chapeau: A person may not—

paragraph.content: provide, attempt to provide, or offer to provide a kickback;
solicit, accept, or attempt to accept a kickback; or

paragraph.chapeau: include the amount of a kickback prohibited by paragraph (1) or (2) in the contract price—

subparagraph.content: a subcontractor charges a prime contractor or a higher tier subcontractor; or
a prime contractor charges the Federal Government.

subsection.heading: Requirements Included in Contracts .—
subsection.chapeau: Each contracting agency shall include in each prime contract awarded by the agency a requirement that the prime contractor shall—

paragraph.content: have in place and follow reasonable procedures designed to prevent and detect violations of section 8702 of this title in its own operations and direct business relationships; and
cooperate fully with a Federal Government agency investigating a violation of section 8702 of this title .

subsection.heading: Full Cooperation Required .—
subsection.content: Notwithstanding subsection (d), a prime contractor shall cooperate fully with a Federal Government agency investigating a violation of section 8702 of this title .

paragraph.heading: In general .—
paragraph.content: A prime contractor or subcontractor that has reasonable grounds to believe that a violation of section 8702 of this title may have occurred shall promptly report the possible violation in writing to the inspector general of the contracting agency, the head of the contracting agency if the agency does not have an inspector general, or the Attorney General.

paragraph.heading: Supplying information as favorable evidence .—
paragraph.content: In an administrative or contractual action to suspend or debar a person who is eligible to enter into contracts with the Federal Government, evidence that the person has supplied information to the Federal Government pursuant to paragraph (1) is favorable evidence of the person’s responsibility for the purposes of Federal procurement laws and regulations.

subsection.heading: Inapplicability to Certain Prime Contracts .—
subsection.chapeau: Subsection (a) does not apply to a prime contract—

paragraph.content: that is not greater than $100,000; or
for the acquisition of commercial products or commercial services (as defined in sections 103 and 103a, respectively, of this title).

subsection.heading: In General .—
subsection.content: To ascertain whether there has been a violation of section 8702 of this title with respect to a prime contract, the Comptroller General and the inspector general of the contracting agency, or a representative of the contracting agency designated by the head of the agency if the agency does not have an inspector general, shall have access to and may inspect the facilities and audit the books and records, including electronic data or records, of a prime contractor or subcontractor under a prime contract awarded by the agency.

subsection.heading: Exception .—
subsection.content: This section does not apply to a prime contract for the acquisition of commercial products or commercial services (as defined in sections 103 and 103a, respectively, of this title).

subsection.heading: Definition .—
subsection.content: In this section, the term “contracting officer” has the meaning given that term in chapter 71 of this title.

subsection.heading: Offset Authority .—
subsection.content: A contracting officer of a contracting agency may offset the amount of a kickback provided, accepted, or charged in violation of section 8702 of this title against amounts the Federal Government owes the prime contractor under the prime contract to which the kickback relates.

paragraph.heading: Withholding and paying over or retaining amounts .—
paragraph.chapeau: On direction of a contracting officer of a contracting agency with respect to a prime contract, the prime contractor shall withhold from amounts owed to a subcontractor under a subcontract of the prime contract the amount of a kickback which was or may be offset against the prime contractor under subsection (b). The contracting officer may order that amounts withheld—

subparagraph.content: be paid over to the contracting agency; or
be retained by the prime contractor if the Federal Government has already offset the amount against the prime contractor.

paragraph.heading: Notice .—
paragraph.content: The prime contractor shall notify the contracting officer when an amount is withheld and retained under paragraph (1)(B).

subsection.heading: Offset, Direction, or Order is Claim of Federal Government .—
subsection.content: An offset under subsection (b) or a direction or order of a contracting officer under subsection (c) is a claim by the Federal Government for the purposes of chapter 71 of this title.

subsection.heading: Amount .—
subsection.chapeau: The Federal Government in a civil action may recover from a person—

paragraph.chapeau: that knowingly engages in conduct prohibited by section 8702 of this title a civil penalty equal to—

subparagraph.content: twice the amount of each kickback involved in the violation; and
not more than $10,000 for each occurrence of prohibited conduct; and

paragraph.content: whose employee, subcontractor, or subcontractor employee violates section 8702 of this title by providing, accepting, or charging a kickback a civil penalty equal to the amount of that kickback.

subsection.heading: Statute of Limitations .—
subsection.chapeau: A civil action under this section must be brought within 6 years after the later of the date on which—

paragraph.content: the prohibited conduct establishing the cause of action occurred; or
the Federal Government first knew or should reasonably have known that the prohibited conduct had occurred.

content.p: A person that knowingly and willfully engages in conduct prohibited by section 8702 of this title shall be fined under title 18, imprisoned for not more than 10 years, or both.
